title: Binham Priory Walk Route

nearby.description: Peddars Way and Norfolk Coast Path

images.title: David Williams / Binham Priory
images.caption: A remarkable building, destroyed in the time of Henry VIII and the dissolution of the monasteries - but now the scene of some inspiring concerts of church music.

images.title: Richard Law / Binham Priory - the gatehouse
images.caption: The former gatehouse to the Priory buildings. This had a Victorian cattleshed in it at one time, which was removed when efforts were made to restore and stabilise the remains. There's still a feeder trough on the inside corner, behind the gateway wall on the left.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Front Street, Binham
images.caption: Front Street, Binham. Looking towards the shop, where the road to the left leads to the church and priory ruins.

images.title: Chequers Inn, Binham by Richard Green, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Chequers Inn, Binham

description: This walk visits the fascinating ancient ruins of Binham Priory in Norfolk. The ruined site dates back to 1091 when it was founded by one of William the Conqueror's nephews. There's also the 13th century priory church which includes a notable rood screen with medieval saints overpainted with Protestant texts. After exploring the extensive monastic ruins the circular walk vists Binham Ford and the Main Street in the village. You can start and finish the walk at the car park at the priory. On the way there are some nice views of the surrounding countryside to enjoy.
